items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of June 10, 2015 through July 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 7. Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions

items.item_details:
By contracting with the State Chancellor's Office, the District may recover outstanding student debts owed such as enrollment fees and library fines.  Under the program, the State Chancellor's Office requests the Franchise Tax Board to offset (deduct) the amount owed to the District from the student's personal State income tax refund, lottery winnings, or other State refund.  The Franchise Tax Board remits any amounts offset to the State Chancellor's Office, who then authorizes the State Controller's Office to disburse the offset amount, less a 25% administrative fee, to the District.
	 
The program is one of a multi-pronged approach to recover outstanding student debts.  The District sends emails to students throughout the term advising of their outstanding balance and providing options to satisfy their outstanding balance (e.g., payment plan, financial aid, etc.).  Upon completion of the term, students who still have an outstanding balance despite receiving emails during the term are sent a letter advising that the balance remains outstanding, that a hold is on their account, the options available to them to satisfy their outstanding balance, and that failure to satisfy the outstanding debt may result in their account being referred to an external collection agency.
	 
Last year, the District referred $2,527,629 in outstanding student debt and recovered $284,074 through the 2015 Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees apprve the contract with the State Chancellor's Office for the District to participate in the 2016 Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP).
items.item_text: Approval of Agreement with the State Chancellor's Office for the 2016 State Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP)
items.item_text_raw: 8. Approval of Agreement with the State Chancellor's Office for the 2016 State Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP)

items.item_details:
Per California’s Public Contract Code Section 20652, the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract the lease, requisition, or purchase order … [to] purchase materials, supplies, equipment … and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase.  The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation or agency.
	 
Authorization to award the contract without advertising for bids by determining it is in the best interest of the District to “piggyback” on an already competitively-bid contract between the listed vendors thru their authorized dealer network.  This “piggy back” option will result in purchase orders with a variety of the vendors listed in GUSD’s board authorized award for School Furnishings, Office Furnishings and Accessories dated February 17, 2015.  It is anticipated that, following selection criteria from user groups and consultants, the District may utilize the Glendale contract piggyback in the purchase of classroom and office furnishings for major bond funded construction projects.
	 
Attached are an affidavit of publication, GUSD’s contract award listing participating vendors.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to ‘piggyback’ on Glendale Unified School District’s (GUSD) contract to purchase School Furnishings, Office Furnishings and Accessories from listed vendors.
items.item_text: Piggyback Glendale Unified School District School Contract for School Furnishings
items.item_text_raw: 9. Piggyback Glendale Unified School District School Contract for School Furnishings

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College is requesting Board approval to participate in overseas travel to increase partnership development and student recruitment to further the campus and Districtâs international education program and services.  EVC is well positioned to further expand our international students program, and the potential to attract international students through partnership growth is strong.   By forming partnerships overseas and escalating our outreach to prospective students, Evergreen aims to become one of the premier institutions for international students in Silicon Valley. 
	 
In recent years government and businesses have also stressed the need for increasing the number of workers in the U.S. who can effectively interact on an international level. A similar message was voiced by President Obama in the State of the Union address on January 25, 2011.  This upward trend calls for a trained workforce that can be effective not only at the national level, but also globally. Evergreen Valley College would be able to reflect the interest the federal government has in establishing new partnerships in advancing the economic, political, and social well-being of U.S.A. here and abroad. 
	 
Staff Attending: Liz Tyrrell, International Program Director; Hue Le, Counselor; Nasreen Rahim, Faculty; Lena Tran, Dean of Business and Workforce.
	 
Proposed dates out of country activities (October 16 Departure to November 7 Return): Cities visited will include: 
Group I: 10/17 Tokyo, 10/22 Singapore, 10/25 Cambodia, and 10/27 to 10/31 Saigon and Da Nang.  
Group II: 10/22 Singapore, 10/25 Bangkok, 10/27 Vietnam, 11/1 Bangladesh, 11/4 India and return 11/7.   
	 
Presentations will include Ministry of Education, high level officials, educational agencies, parents, and students.  Partnerships development and recruitment initiatives will include: agent expos, education briefings, school visits, and student events.
	 
Partnership development with universities, colleges and other educational providers, including recruitment and fair participation are the best opportunities for EVC to achieve greater visibility and creditability.   As the college is entering the international educational market, we will develop strategic partnerships with educational institutions and educational organizations. Evergreen Valley College has been selected to participate in Asia recruitment events and partnership engagements offered through American International Recruitment Council (AIRC) and Vietnam Education & Training Center (VETEC) due to the high demand in Asia to study in the United States.  VETEC is a reputable agency in providing recruitment events such as visits to local schools, college student fairs and agent workshops.  Tokyo and Singapore are the education hubs in Asia, AIRC is a trustworthy non-profit organization that provides guidance and best practices for partnerships development among colleges, universities, and agencies.
	 
Since Evergreen Valley College is located in Silicon Valley/Bay Area, our region is well-known worldwide contributing to the collegeâs branding overseas.  Our international branding and meetings with educational institutions and organizations will serve as a gateway for many students to start or complete their educational goals at EVC.  Additionally, having international students be a vibrant part of our campus provides domestic students with an opportunity to study and interact with other students from around the world. The cultural enrichment that occurs through having international students broadens the kind of education that enables students to achieve a better understanding of the world around them and encourages them to more fully participate in it.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out of country travel to Asia for recruitment and partnership development purposes.
items.item_text: Out of Country Travel to Asia - Recruitment and Partnership Development
items.item_text_raw: 11. Out of Country Travel to Asia - Recruitment and Partnership Development

items.item_details:
The Family TIES Mother-Daughter STEM Initiative is an innovative program that seeks to expose low-income, first-generation female prospective college students to the STEM related opportunities available to them in the Silicon Valley by enrolling them, together with an adult female household member, in an introductory course in a STEM related discipline. 
	 
The program encourages teamwork at home and in the classroom and encourages family members to study together and to succeed together. It will also challenge women to work together to succeed in STEM and provide a welcoming and non-threatening all-female cohort learning experience that will emphasize female leadership roles in STEM related disciplines. In addition, it seeks to improve the economic stability of low-income families by encouraging adult, female household members to obtain an AA/AS degree.
	 
The Family TIES initiative will achieve the following goals:
	 
Expose high-school female students to college level coursework in a 2-year college environment. 
Demystify the college campus and course enrollment process by actively engaging adult female household members in the education of their prospective college enrollee. 
Increase the comfort level of hesitant young students and their parent/guardian by bringing them to campus and engaging them in all the EVC campus offers.  
Provide low-income students with a free credit-granting course, giving them a "head start" as they achieve their educational goals. 
Encourage low-income, adult, female household members to continue their education at EVC and emphasize the economic benefit of obtaining a STEM AA/AS degree. 
	 
The program will enroll 10 mothers and 10 daughters for each area; Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics.
	 
	 
Description
Amount
Tuition for each cohort (20x4) with courses ranging 3-5 units
15,000
Student Success (tutoring, study skills, personal and classroom counseling, time and stress management)
4,000
Supplies and books 
3,000
Career Readiness (Shadowing Day, Mentoring  Monday, Resumes, LinkedIn)
3,000
Recruitment (outreach, bi-lingual fliers, digital campaign, radio)
3,000
Operations Expenses
2,000

items.item_details:
As part of the Automotive Technology Building Project, the Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Department has requested new and upgraded equipment for the program, including instructional courseware from ATech Training, Inc.  While the total purchase is over the statutory bid threshold, we recommend proceeding without bidding since:  this is educational courseware; it will be networked in with existing ATech courseware; and it can only be purchased from this source.
	 
The ATech Training courseware purchase includes: automotive electronics computer based instruction software, hands-on activities with computer animation, troubleshooting practice and competency testing, student performance recording, and all related equipment.  ATech Training, Inc. has more than 25 years of experience with automotive technology instructional courseware used by automotive industry leaders and is currently used in hundreds of public and private educational institutions. 
This purchase of educational courseware is exempt from statutory bid requirements (Education Code 81651).  This Education Code allows the governing board of any community college district to purchase supplementary textbooks, library books, and educational films, audiovisual materials, test materials, workbooks, instructional computer software packages, or periodicals in any amount needed for the operation of the schools of the district without taking estimates or advertising for bids.
	 
 ATech Training, Inc. is the proprietary (sole source) provider of this courseware (see attached letter).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the proprietary (sole source) purchase of automotive technology courseware and equipment from ATech Training, Inc. in the amount of $121,749.91.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 – Proprietary Purchase of Courseware
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 – Proprietary Purchase of Courseware

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 005 includes the addition of 19 Wireless Access Points, the addition of storefront flashing, cost to provide off-site recycled water to the Automotive Technology Building site for construction activity use and a deductive change order for Division of the State Architect (DSA) review of Air Handling Unit housekeeping pad Structural engineering calculations.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $     477,250
Change Order No. 005                                     $     181,374   
Total Contract and Changes                             $12,006,328
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $658,624, which equates to 5.80% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 005 in the amount of $181,374 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On August 5, 2015 a proposal was received from Eagle Enterprises for the complete inspector of record services for the Evergreen Valley College (EVC) MDF Relocation Project (#39310) in the amount of $14,950.00.  Due to the size and scope of this Project only part-time inspection services are required.  
	 
Since Eagle Enterprises is providing the inspector of record services per contract for the EVC Central Green and Arts Plaza Project currently under construction and adjacent to the EVC MDF Relocation Project, this Agreement will provide added value and cost savings to the District and this Project as they are already present on Campus for the duration of this Project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of an Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) to Eagle Enterprises in the amount of $14,950.00 for Inspector of Record Services for the Evergreen Valley College (EVC) MDF Relocation Project (#39310).

items.item_details:
On October 10, 2013 the Board approved a Contract to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects for design, construction administration and Division of the State Architect (DSA) coordination of the Central Green Project.  The project involves a renovation of existing pedestrian accessibility routes, hardscape, softscape, trees/plants/soil, irrigation, exterior wayfinding signage and exterior lighting.  The project will require review and approval by the Division of State Architect.
	 
Revision No. 002 includes additional design and construction administration services, electrical and structural design for power, data and telecommunications conduit layout routing into the Student Services Building in support of Main Data Frame (MDF) Relocation Project.  The work also includes structural design for the existing utility tunnel/basement equipment access cover at the Student Services Building.
    
Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include design, construction administration and DSA coordination.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms. 
	 
Original Contract Amount                   $    226,750
Previous Change Order(s)                  $      50,000
Revision N. 002                                  $      11,700
Revised Contract Amount                  $    288,450
	 
The net change to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects contract as a result of all changes issued is $61,700, which equates to 27.21% of the base contract.   A significant scope change, required by DSA to provide an Americas with Disabilities Act compliant path of travel to the new South Campus Development Project, was added into the Central Green / Arts Plaza project, in Revision No. 001.  The contract duration is not being changed by this Revision.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) No. 02 Revision No. 002 in the amount of $11,700 to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects for the Central Green / Arts Plaza Project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District request design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Deductive Change Order No. 009 includes Work that is the result of:  deleting the Work Service Modular Enhanced (WSME) wire molding in the lecture room tables as they are furnished with integrated power, adding single-ply roofing membrane to the inside face of the parapet walls, increasing the width of the exterior walls at the Fitness Center, providing additional network pathways for new Main Data Frame (MDF) connection, clarifying framing/soffit details at the skylights, and revising door swings at the Fitness Center to allow for required pull side clearances.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.  
	 
Original Contract Amount                     $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes               $      450,271.00
Deductive Change Order No. 009       $       (22,609.00)
Total Contract and Changes                $42,067,391.00
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $427,662.00 which equates to 1.03% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from the project contingency established in the project budget.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Deductive Change Order No. 009 in the amount of ($22,609.00) to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Deductive Change Order No. 009

items.item_details:
The Board previously approved Dougherty and Dougherty Architects to provide design services for the Evergreen Valley College MDF Relocation Project #39310.  The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on June 25th and July 2, 2015 and published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to all potential contractors including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  A Mandatory Job Walk was conducted at 9:00 AM July 16th with the Architect, District Purchasing, Construction Manager and potential contractors in attendance. 
	 
On July 30th construction bids were received on that design.  Base bids were received as follows:
	 
Rodan Builders, Inc.                $   947,000
Taber Construction, Inc.          $   996,000
California Plus Engineering     $1,200,000
Zolman Construction               $1,040,000
	 
Rodan Builders, Inc. from Burlingame, CA was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder in the amount of $947,000.00.  There were no specified alternates or unit pricing required as part of this bid.  An allowance of $13,000 has been added to the base bid amount of this Contract for Scope that is required to complete this Project that was not captured in the Bid Documents.  This brings the total value of the Contract to $960,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of a contract in the amount of $960,000.00 to Rodan Builders, Inc., for the Main Data Frame (MDF) Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G –2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Main Data Frame (MDF) Relocation Project #39310 – Rodan Builders, Inc. Notice of Award – Construction
items.item_text_raw: 9. Measure G –2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Main Data Frame (MDF) Relocation Project #39310 – Rodan Builders, Inc. Notice of Award – Construction

items.item_details:
This agenda item is for the purchase of 260 indoor Wireless Access Points and 91 outdoor Wireless Access Points to be installed throughout Evergreen Valley College for use by students, staff, faculty, administrators and guests. This is a continuation of the EVC Wireless Upgrade starter project that was approved by the Board on April 14, 2015 and included the purchase and installation of 111 indoor WAPs and 25 outdoor WAPs. This agenda item does not include installation services or extra cabling - those items will be included in a future agenda.
	 
	 
This wireless upgrade is part of an overall network infrastructure modernization (Measure G-2010 Bond Project 32702) and a new Main Distribution Facility (MDF) (Measure G-2010 Bond Project 39310). The full bandwidth utilization of these new WAPs will not be realized until the new MDF is installed along with new fiber optics cabling from the MDF to the campus buildings and the installation of the new network switches. 
	 
This purchase is based on RFP # G2010.0099 and pursuant to the Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies approved by the board on 8/26/14 (Measure G-2010 Bond Program).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of Wireless Access Points for Evergreen Valley College through Dasher Technologies for a total cost of $286,629.72.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Wireless Access Points for Evergreen Valley College

On April 8, 2014 the Board of Trustees agreed to enter into a contract with LPAS, Inc. for Professional Services which includes Design Development, Construction Documents, DSA Approval, Bid Documents, Contractor Pre-Qualification, Contractor Selection and Bidding, Construction Administration, and Close-Out/Post-Construction/Occupancy in the amount of $1,474,788  for the Physical Education Building  #122 at San Jose City College.
	 
On October 28, 2014 the Board agreed to amend the agreement in the amount of $74,875 for Site Work Design and Landscape Design.
	 
On May 26, 2015 the Board agreed to amend the agreement in the amount of $15,000 for Concessions & Visiting Team Rooms Programming and Conceptual Design Services.
Amendment No. 003 includes, providing site electrical and telecommunications design services.  LPAS, Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for changes that include additional work.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
	 
	 
The item in this Amendment results in an addition to the contract of $17,000.
	 
         Original Contract Amount       $1,474,788
         Previous Approved Revisions       89,875
         This Revision No. 003                   17,000
                 
         Total Contract and Changes    $1,581,663

On June 9, 2015 the Board approved a contract to Lewis and Tibbitts, Inc., in the amount of $447,075.48 to provide construction services for the Pathway / Parking Lot Improvement Project at the SJCC. 
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 001 is for changes necessary to ensure ADA compliant parking access for buildings 100 and 200, accessible concrete sidewalk improvements, concrete removal in the parking lot and building 200 sleeve to roof drain leader change to meet asphalt grading requirements. 
	 
Lewis and Tibbitts, Inc., submitted  written pricing proposals for changes (detailed in the attachment) that include additional or deleted materials, equipment, labor, time extensions as applicable and the prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                    $447,075.48
Previously Approved Changes            $           0.00  
Change Order No. 001                        $  44,677.00
	 
Revised Contract Amount                    $491,752.48
	 
The net change to Lewis and Tibbitts, Inc., contract as a result of all changes issued is $44,677.00 which equates to 9.9% of the base contract. This change will be funded from project contingency.  No additional funding is required.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001 in the amount of $44,677.00 to Lewis and Tibbitts, Inc., for the Pathway/Parking Lot Improvements at San Jose City College (SJCC).

items.item_details:
As part of the South Campus Development project, the design team engaged a fitness consultant (MediFit) to perform a detailed study of the equipment needs of the Physical Education Department in order to determine; user needs, functionality and performance for use in the new South Campus Development Project, Fitness Center at Evergreen Valley College (EVC).  Detailed equipment specifications were generated and reviewed by the District, MediFit and the District’s furniture, Fixtures and Equipment consultant, KRJ.  The resulting requirements for the new cardio equipment were put out for public bid.  (A second public bid is being conducted for the strength equipment for the fitness center).
	 
The public bidding process for vendors was conducted between July 31 and August 13, 2015.  The project was advertised in local papers on ­­­­­7/29/15, 8/5/2015.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to local and national potential vendors.  Seven potential bidders requested bid packages.  Bids were opened at 3:00 pm on August 13, 2015.    
	 
Three (3) bids were received.  A selection committee that included college teaching staff, the fitness consultant, the FF&E consultant and District purchasing evaluated the bid responses.  The selection committee reviewed the bid unit prices and evaluated several proposed alternates in relation to bid specifications (which including suitability for user population, user interface and maintenance considerations).  Based on the selection committee’s evaluation, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award contracts to the companies and in the not-to-exceed amounts listed below:
	 
Precor Incorporated                            $ 170,912.00
Precor Commercial Fitness                 $   75,693.00
LifeFitness                                           $     4,089.00
Total Cost:                                          $ 250,694.00
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Independent Contractor Agreements not-to-exceed the amount indicated to the following cardio equipment vendors: Precor Incorporated ($170,912), Precor Commercial Fitness ($75,693) and LifeFitness ($4,089) for a total amount of $250,694 for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details: The Board of Trustees adopted the District's operating budget at its meeting of September 9, 2014.  As required by Board Policy 6250, subsequent budget transfers and revisions must be approved by the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Education Code 81378.1, the Board of Trustees may lease District property for a period of no more than five years through direct negotiation with interested parties after a declaration of its intent to lease real property. As such, the District is seeking approval of the attached resolution number 082515-3 in support of leasing the administrative office space located at 4750 San Felipe Road to local, nonprofit organizations that share the District’s vision and mission, as supported in the District Global Ends Policies.
	 
The attached resolution number 082515-2 represents an update to resolution number 071415-5, that failed to pass at the July 14, 2015 Board meeting.  A change has been made to this resolution to further specify that “Since the buildings are not certified by the Division of State Architect (DSA) allowing for student occupancy and usage, the lessee shall not permit student usage of any type, including, but not limited to, classroom or instructional purposes.”
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the attached resolution number 082515-2 in support of leasing the vacated 4750 San Felipe Road Administration Buildings.
items.item_text: Resolution 082515-2 in support of lease of office space in the vacated 4750 San Felipe Road Administration Buildings
items.item_text_raw: 2. Resolution 082515-2 in support of lease of office space in the vacated 4750 San Felipe Road Administration Buildings

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, the following additional criteria has been added to the Bond List Revision process and is being implemented with this Bond List Revision. Whenever a Bond List Revision Approval Request proposes a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, or cancels a project from the bond list, or creates a new project, the associated agenda item will contain additional information about the proposed change to the project or project(s).  This information will be more comprehensive than that which is contained in the Bond List Revision Approval Request report.  Additionally, projects that meet the above criteria will receive a footnote that cross references to a legend at the bottom of the Bond List Revision Approval Request form identifying the criteria the change falls under.
	 
Bond List Revision No. 15 includes the following revisions: interest earnings allocations, the recognition of project savings and the realignment of budget at Evergreen Valley College.  
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 15 dated August 25, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 15
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 15

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2004 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2004 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, the following additional criteria has been added to the Bond List Revision process and is being implemented with this Bond List Revision.  Whenever a Bond List Revision Approval Request proposes a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, or cancels a project from the bond list, or creates a new project, the associated agenda item will contain additional information about the proposed change to the project or project(s).  This information will be more comprehensive than that which is contained in the Bond List Revision Approval Request report.  Additionally, projects that meet the above criteria will receive a footnote that cross references to a legend at the bottom of the Bond List Revision Approval Request form identifying the criteria the change falls under.
	 
This Bond List Revision request includes allocation of interest earnings.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on the project revision included on the G-2004 Bond List Revision dated August 25, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
